data.name: Declare lost dog
data.description: Action to declare a dog is lost by the owner.

threats.title: User falsely reports someone else's dog as lost
threats.description: User falsely reports someone else's dog as lost and claims it as their own.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Require authentication for declaring a lost dog to ensure that only the dog’s legitimate owner can report it as lost, for example requiring users to login by implementing owner accounts connected to registered dogs. 
2.	Use CAPTCHA to prevent robots from impersonating legitimate owners. 
3.	Authenticate ownership using a private key / access token held by the owner of the dog not stored in the system.

threats.title: Adversary in the middle attack
threats.description: An adversary in the middle intercepts the lost dog request and modifies the information being transmitted.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Use a unique session ID with an HTTP-only secure connection and secure cookies. 
2.	Hash the lost dog request with the owner’s private key. 
3.	Implement strict server-side input validation to stop malicious data manipulation through the form for declaring a lost dog.

threats.title: User declares a lost dog with an email they don't own
threats.description: A user who is not the owner declares a lost dog with an email they don’t own, then the owner denies having made this report, but it is difficult to prove otherwise.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Hash the lost dog request with the user’s private key, to ensure the authenticity of lost dog declarations. This can help verify who made the request. 
2.	Send a confirmation email with a unique token to confirm that the user who declared the lost dog owns the email.

threats.title: Owner's private information is leaked
threats.description: The owner’s private email address becomes exposed to malicious entities or unauthorised users.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Ensure that all communication between the user and the system is carried out over HTTP to protect transmitted data.

threats.title: Direct network flood by malicious user
threats.description: One user overloads the system with requests to declare a lost dog, causing the site to crash or become unresponsive. Users can no longer declare dogs as lost.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Use a web application firewall to detect and block suspicious traffic patterns, such as a sudden spike in lost dog declarations from the same IP address. 
2.	Block repeated requests from the same origin IP. 
3.	Disallow repeated requests for the same dog if the dog lost status is already lost.

threats.title: Unregistered dog can be declared lost
threats.description: A user is able to declare an unregistered dog as lost.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Apply least privilege principle by creating a user account when a user registers a dog, so that the user can only declare that dog as lost when logged in. 
2.	Check the owner’s email and dog’s name against the information stored in the database to check that the dog is registered before a user can make a declare lost dog request.

threats.title: User falsely submits lost dog report pretending to be the dog owner
threats.description: Attacker exploits web protocols (HTTP / HTTPS) to submit a lost dog report using the dog owner’s email and dog’s name.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Implement network detection and prevention systems that use network signatures specific to malicious activity. This can be used to mitigate unauthorised actions at the network level.

threats.title: Abuse elevation control mechanism
threats.description: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism – Attacker submits a lost dog report using the owner’s email and dog name but denies doing so.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Privileged account management – require owners to have a password to access the declare lost dog feature. 
2.	Execution prevention – disallow lost dog forms unsigned with the owner’s private key from being submitted.

data.name: Dog data store
data.description: Data store containing dog name, lost status, tag ID,  and owner information (first name, last name, pronoun, email, address)

threats.title: Stored data manipulation
threats.description: Stored data manipulation – a malicious user can gain access to the dog data store and modify information such as the last known tag ID and dog lost status.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Encrypt information stored in the dog data store
2.	Use remote data storage to backup information stored in the dog data store, allowing data to be restore in case of a data breach. 
3.	Restrict file and directory permissions. Apply the principle of least privilege to ensure that only maintainers of the dog registration system can access and manipulate the dog data store directly.

threats.title: Unauthorised user access
threats.description: An unauthorised user gains access to the dog data store.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Apply least privilege principle – only maintainer accounts have access to the database, with passwords securely stored in password vaults.

threats.title: Firmware corruption
threats.description: Firmware corruption – a malicious user corrupts the firmware of the storage devices used by the dog data store, leading to data being lost or inaccessible.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Boot integrity – check integrity of current firmware of dog data store to assess vulnerability to modification. 
2.	Privileged account management – implement security measures to stop attackers gaining control over privileged accounts that have access to the firmware of the dog data store. 
3.	Update software – Patch the firmware where necessary to prevent exploitation of known vulnerabilities.

data.name: Confirmation message
data.description: Confirms dog lost status is lost and contains last known tag id of dog.

threats.title: Data manipulation
threats.description: Data manipulation – an attacker alters the content of the confirmation message to the dog owner.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt information in the confirmation message to prevent it from being altered, such as the dog tag id.

threats.title: Network sniffing
threats.description: Network sniffing – an attacker uses network sniffing tools to intercept the confirmation message, gaining access to the owner’s personal information such as name and email address.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Encrypt sensitive information. Ensure that all web traffic containing credentials is protected by SSL / TLS. 
2.	Network segmentation. Deny direct access of broadcasts and multicast sniffing.

threats.title: Service stop
threats.description: Service stop – an attacker exploits a vulnerability in the messaging service to stop confirmation messages being sent.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Restrict registry permissions – ensure proper registry permissions are implemented so that malicious users cannot interfere with the confirmation message service. 
2.	User account management – ensure that only council administrators can interact with the confirmation message configuration. 
3.	Network segmentation – Operate intrusion detection, response and analysis systems on a separate network to the production environment for the dog registration system. This makes it less likely for a malicious user to interfere with the confirmation message function.

data.name: Last known tag ID
data.description: Last known tag ID of reported lost dog.

threats.title: Transmitted data manipulation
threats.description: Transmitted data manipulation – an attacker intercepts the data transmission and alters the last known tag ID of the dog during transmission.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt the dog’s last known tag ID during transmission to reduce the impact of data alterations on data in transit.

threats.title: Network denial of service
threats.description: Network denial of service – an attacker floods the system with lost dog requests, overwhelming the system and preventing the dog’s last known tag id from being retrieved successfully.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Use a web application firewall to detect and block suspicious traffic patterns, such as a sudden spike in lost dog declarations from the same IP address. 
2.	Block repeated requests from the same origin IP. 
3.	Disallow repeated requests for the same dog if the dog lost status is already lost.

data.name: Dog lost status updates to lost
data.description: Lost status of dog in dog data store is updated to lost.

threats.title: Transmitted data manipulation
threats.description: Transmitted data manipulation – an attacker intercepts the data transmission and alters the lost status of the dog during transmission.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt the dog’s lost status during transmission to reduce the impact of data alterations on data in transit.

threats.title: Endpoint denial of service
threats.description: Endpoint denial of service – an attacker floods the system with lost dog requests, overwhelming the system and preventing the status update process from completing successfully.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Use a web application firewall to detect and block suspicious traffic patterns, such as a sudden spike in lost dog declarations from the same IP address. 
2.	Block repeated requests from the same origin IP. 
3.	Disallow repeated requests for the same dog if the dog lost status is already lost.

labels: Dog lost status updates to lost

data.name: Login Information
data.description: User provides email and password as login information.

threats.title: Transmitted data manipulation
threats.description: An attacker intercepts the data transmission and alters the user login information during transmission.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt the user's login information during transmission to reduce the impact of data alterations on data in transit.

threats.title: Attacker intercepts user login details
threats.description: Attacker gains access to user login details during transmission.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt sensitive information. Ensure that all web traffic containing credentials is protected by SSL / TLS.

threats.title: Service stop
threats.description: Service stop – an attacker exploits a vulnerability in the login service to prevent legitimate users from logging in.
threats.mitigation:
1.	Restrict registry permissions – ensure proper registry permissions are implemented so that malicious users cannot interfere with the login service service. 
2.	Network segmentation – Operate intrusion detection, response and analysis systems on a separate network to the production environment for the dog registration system. This makes it less likely for a malicious user to interfere with the login function.

data.name: Login response
data.description: If login information is accepted or rejected.

threats.title: Transmitted data manipulation
threats.description: Transmitted data manipulation – adversary alters lost dog information en route to manipulate external outcomes, threatening the integrity of the data.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Encrypt sensitive information: encrypt all information in the lost dog information data flow to reduce the impact of alterations on transmitted data.

threats.title: Gather owner identity information
threats.description: Gather victim identity information – owner email addresses. An attacker can gather information about a dog owner that can then be used for malicious purposes.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Minimise the amount of information available to external entities.

threats.title: Network denial of service
threats.description: Network denial of service – an attacker sends a flood of traffic to the server, causing the data flow to be disrupted.
threats.mitigation: 1.	Filter network traffic. Intercept incoming traffic upstream to filter out attack traffic from legitimate traffic when the volume of traffic exceeds the capacity of the network connection.

data.name: Login
data.description: User is logged in to the dog registration system

threats.title: Owner is impersonated due to login credentials stolen
threats.description: A malicious user impersonates a legitimate owner by obtaining their login credentials.
threats.mitigation:
1. Implement multi factor authentication 
2. Account lockout mechanism 
3. Strong password policies 
4. CAPTCHA

threats.title: Data modified during login process
threats.description: An attacker intercepts and modifies user data during transmission, for example user email and password.
threats.mitigation:
1. Transport layer security: encrypt data in transit 
2. Integrity checks: use hash-based message authentication codes to check data integrity
3. Input validation: validate and sanitise all user data

threats.title: User denies logging in
threats.description: A user is able to deny logging in, meaning actions taken on their account cannot be traced back to them.
threats.mitigation:
1. Digital signatures - ensure actions can be traced back to the user by using a personal digital signature to log in
2. Maintain logs of login attempts including information such as timestamps and a IP addresses

threats.title: User login details made public
threats.description: User login details such as password and email are exposed during the login process.
threats.mitigation:
1. Encrypt stored passwords using strong algorithms
2. Secure session management
3. Use generic error messages so it is unknown whether the username or password is incorrect

threats.title: Login system overloaded with requests
threats.description: A malicious user overloads the login process with requests to login, cause the process to crash and making it unavailable to legitimate users.
threats.mitigation:
1. Rate limiting to restrict the number of login attempts from a single IP address in a certain time period. 
2. Use a web application firewall to detect and block suspicious traffic patterns.

threats.title: Attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the login process to gain higher access levels
threats.description: Attacker exploits vulnerabilities in the login process to gain higher access levels than they are authorised for, for example access to data stores.
threats.mitigation:
1. Role based access control - users only have access to the resources and actions they are authorised for
2. Use security patches to protect against known vulnerabilities 
3. Implement secure coding practices in the login process
